Title.evidence: Hemodynamic Characteristics of Type II Endoleaks: A Randomised Controlled Trial

Trial_Design.evidence: Sample size calculation was based on detecting significant differences in TEC parameters, assuming a power of 0.8 and a significance level of 0.05.

Participants.evidence: 45 participants at a single center between April 2017 and April 2022.

Intervention.evidence: Participants were randomised into two groups: 20 patients with type II endoleaks identified within 1 week after endovascular aortic repair (EVAR) and 25 patients with persistent type II endoleaks diagnosed during follow-up imaging.

Objective.evidence: This study aimed to explore the hemodynamic characteristics of type II endoleaks using mathematical simulations and validate these findings with clinical data from four-dimensional computed tomography (4D-CT).

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the consistency between simulation results and clinical time-enhanced curves (TECs) from 4D-CT.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was performed using a computer-generated sequence, and allocation was concealed.

Number_Randomised.evidence: 45 participants at a single center between April 2017 and April 2022.

Result_Outcome.evidence: Significant differences in TEC parameters were observed between stable and enlarged groups, with 80% enhancement duration (AUC, 0.88; sensitivity, 0.87; specificity, 0.80), peak-to-peak time feeder (AUC, 0.78; sensitivity, 0.93; specificity, 0.60), and upslope (AUC, 0.86; sensitivity, 0.73; specificity, 0.93) being most informative.
